dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A curtain of rain falls across the treetops descending up soft green hills and the patchwork farmsteads. A dog comes running along the crest of a hill, rejoicing, at the rain. The dog skids to a halt, shaking itself, turning its snou toward the fading light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A log spits on the hearth, sending firelight across the u and the gaunt figure of EDWARD PRENDICK, who sits hunched semi-darkness, half listening to a COMPACT DISC RECORDING bluesy romantic ballad. Prendick glances down at the tabletop, at the piles of no and the dense, crabbed handwriting that covers them, at t repeated sketches and doodles representing what we will c recognize as the emblem of the Tree of Life; at the empty coffee cups, the overflowing ashtray and the dismem pieces of the 38 pistol that lie before him. He touches a button on a REMOTE CONTROL and the singing s next touches the button on a TAPE RECORDER which whirrs t life. As Prendick speaks as he reaches down and begins to assem gun, his eyes unreadable, his lids red and bruised from l sleep, a week's growth of stubble on his waxy cheeks. His are slow and deliberate.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: In a spirit of complete honesty, I want to say right from the start that I think we've made some really incredible mistakes about God. we tell ourselves that He's all-powerful, when we really should be questioning His competence. Believe me, I'm not asking for miracles. A little adult leadership would do. Prendick brushes aside the papers on his desk and gropes impatiently for a box of cartridges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As for God's love, all I know for certain is that He loves our suffering. And as for His power... well, maybe He can do whatever He wants with us, but there's one thing I'm pretty certain He can't do. When he's sick of existing, He can't end it. Only we can do that... Prendick opens the box and begins to load the revolver; s cartridges. Then he stops, laughs, shakes his head, and e all but one cartridge.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: My name's Edward Prendick. Until about ten years ago I was a lawyer, specializing in what was mis-named Human Rights. In August of 2007, I was travelling as Special Envoy for the United Nations as a part of the effort to stop the bloody civil war in Micronesia. That's where it began. This is where it will end. Prendick raises the revolver and almost touches it to his savoring the moment of his obliteration. THUNDER CRASHES on the soundtrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are flying. Soaring above tropical rainclouds, mist stretching away b illuminated from within by pulsing veins of lightning. The canopy of cloud parts, giving way to a limitless vist open sea, a horizon so vast that one can almost see the c the earth.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Our plane went down in a magnetic storm just above the equator at roughly 1655 longitude. We see a yellow dot in the distance now, a tiny life raft a world of water. There are THREE MEN aboard, two of them wearing the unifo United Nations peacekeeping force and the third, Prendick in the remains of a bedraggled threepiece suit, a life ja around his neck. The two soldiers, one Nordic, the other vaguely Hispanic locked in a violent struggle while Prendick tries ineffec separate them.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We'd been adrift four days when the fever hit us. SOLDIER 1(Hispanic) Stay away from me!

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Leave him.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER 2
dialogues.text: He can't last. His water can save us.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Leave him! We can make it through this. They'll find us! Soldier 2 doesn't reply; instead he makes a lunge for his throat. Prendick tries to grab the soldier's legs but the rolls heavily and he loses his grip. The soldier administ savage kick to his head and he goes down, one hand raised protect his face, the other reaching for the flare gun. T soldier has his hands around the first soldier's throat a of them grapple desperately, locked in a death grip. Prendick raises the flare gun, levelling it at soldier 2' his hand shaking.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Let him go, you son of a bitch! The man releases his companion who crumples to the floor raft, retching and gasping for breath. He turns slowly to face Prendick, staring with sun-glazed the wavering barrel of the flare gun.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER 2
dialogues.text: You're some fucking lawyer. Don't â€˜you know the first law of nature is survival.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: We're not animals! The soldier eyes Prendick up and down, afraid to call his Then, with a yell, the soldier 1 springs at him, a surviv glinting in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER 1
dialogues.text: Cabron! Both men are screaming now, soldier 2 is driven back as h comrade drives his blade into him, blood going everywhere The soldier pulls away, staring in disbelief at his wound to get to his feet but the first soldier plunges the knif again. He doubles up, emitting a grunt, his hands graspin his assailant. The dinghy pitches heavily to one side and the wounded so overboard, dragging his comrade with him. He sinks like a stone but his murderer struggles for a mo breaking free of his grip and trying to stay afloat as Pr reaches out to him. Then there is a white flash in the water and he is dragge with barely a yell, the life raft shivering as the creatu deep brush against its underside, jostling each other as Prendick collapses to the floor of the dinghy with a groa He lies staring at the sky for a moment, alone now with t sea. Slowly he begins to laugh, his laughter growing grad louder and more uncontrollable. He raises the gun and squeezing the trigger sends a white flare arcing up into the vault of the sky.

dialogues.speaker: THE DISC OF THE SUN
dialogues.text: A dazzling, overexposed white. The SOUND of the hissing flare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick lies in the bottom of the dinghy watching the sw horizon, his eyes unfocused, his face raw and blistered f relentless sun. His head sways with the rise and fall of the ocean and al horizon seems to sway with him, the earth and the sky and shining crack that separates them. A dark smudge appears on the far horizon. Dancing. Drawi He closes his eyes. When he opens them again he sees the side of the freighte over him, a row of figures gathered at the rail, outlines against the sun. A MAN with a droopy Zapata moustache and sad eyes, his lo hair tied back in a tail, an OLDER MAN, his angry, freckl framed by red hair and lastly, standing beside them as if fever dream is the third man, a DARK MAN whose eyes shine feverishly. Hands lift Prendick. Dark, powerful hands. His head lolls back and he knows no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a CLOSEUP of the MAN with the moustache, (MONTGOME looking solicitously down at Prendick. Prendick groans.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Easy now, ole' buddy. Prendick opens his eyes to find himself in a small untidy crammed with specimen jars containing gaudy tropical orch A low animal SNARL comes from somewhere outside the cabin Prendick glances around himself uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Feel better?

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You're okay. Don't worry. Prendick looks nervously down at himself as if to make su all still there. Montgomery smiles reassuringly.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Who are you?  Prendick Prendick

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: My name's Montgomery.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: What ship is this?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: This shitbucket's the Ipecacuanha. Sounds like a drug doesn't it? (smiles) We all dropped Ipecacuanha and bayed at the moon. is aware that he's in the company of a real character.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: My name's Edward Prendick. I have to get to Bougainville... I'm an international lawyer on assignment for the U.N.... they'll be looking for me... sits up, tries to stand. Montgomery gently pushes him back. Prendick is now aware he's on an IV.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Easy, Eddie, just relax. I'm still hydrating you. In two days you'll be in Port Moresby, you can contact your people there.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Moresby's our first stop?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Second. They have to land me first.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: An island... where I live. But there's limited communications... no one you could call from there.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: A remote island... (dares a smile) Everyman's dream.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Right, now it's your turn to dream. I'm gonna give you a shot. Montgomery holds up a hypodermic needle, tenderly pats P arm, and administers a shot.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Trust me blindly. You'll like it.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Are you a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Let's say I'm a para-medic. There is another burst of feral SNARLING from outside and there is a man's voice as well.

dialogues.speaker: GOD DAMN IT
dialogues.text: Prendick glances up at the cabin ceiling and the directio muffled yells.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: That's a great shot I just gave you, Edward. I've known people who'd sell their grandmothers for a shot like that, so don't piss it away. Try and get some sleep. Prendick relaxes and the cabin goes blurry around the edg more as the sleeping potion begins to take effect.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: There you go, Eddie... Dream... Prendick's eyes wander down onto the lettering stencilled one of the packing cases: 'DESTINATION: U.S. BIOSTATION, DELTA VIA SUVA.' And from somewhere on deck the cries sta again, as Prendick drifts slowly down into oblivion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consciousness washes slowly back into Prendick's mind as himself watching a puddle of sunlight stretch slowly acro cabin ceiling. Prendick sits up to see that the cabin door is standing a fresh set of clothes are laid out for him at the foot of He gets slowly to his feet, rubbing his head catching a glimpse of his sun-scarred face in the cabin mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick glances about the freighter deck, blinking in th sunshine, not prepared by the SOUNDS for what he sees. The whole deck is littered with scraps of carrots, shreds stuff and indescribable filth. All along the starboard bulwark are big hutches filled wi and there is a solitary llama squeezed into a cage forwar number of grisly staghounds are fastened to the rail by m chains and in the center of the deck a huge black leopard cramped in a small iron cage. A short FIGURE (M'LING) sit the cage. There is something particularly arresting about M'Ling's slightest elongation of his features and an almost feral that informs his expression. He gets to his feet and starts suddenly towards Prendick, glow of excitement in his face. Prendick takes a step backwards and almost bumps into Mon who has appeared from the hatchway behind him and who now past to come between Prendick and M'Ling. M'Ling steps back as if afraid.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: God damn it, M'Ling, what the hell's the matter with you? I told you to stay forward.

dialogues.speaker: M'LING
dialogues.text: They... won't have me forward... They say I disturb the animals.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Come on, man, don't give me that bullshit. I told you to fucking STAY FORWARD! You want me to tell Dr. Moreau about this? M'Ling turns slowly and moves away. Montgomery turns, gla nervously back at Prendick.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: What are these animals? They are interrupted by a loud YELP and a VOLLEY OF CURS companionway. M'Ling runs pathetically back onto the deck by a heavy, red-haired MAN in a white cap. M'Ling hesitat sees Montgomery and the red haired man catches up to him, striking him between the shoulder blad sending him sprawling into the midst of the furiously bar staghounds. The red-haired man staggers onto the deck and Montgomery towards him angrily.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Hey, Captain, lighten up. That man is a paid passenger. So tell your crew to keep their filthy hands off of him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Or what?? I do what I like on my own ship! Davis turns away and staggers across to the rail, Montgom following him.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You've been hassling my man there since we got on board. (Under his breath, to Prendick) Most obvious case of drug psychosis I've ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Drug what!? What're you talking about there?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Maritime Law. This man happens to be a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Here's the maritime law on my ship. (He pulls out a pistol.) I don't like freaks aboard, you hippy burn-out. Montgomery turns away as Davis shouts after him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: He comes to this end of the ship again and I'll cut his guts out! The animals go crazy when they smell him. Prendick feels impelled to step in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute. I'm a Special Envoy for the United Nations...

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: You're tits on a bull so you stay out of this... United Nations... Freeloading bastard, taking up space on my ship. Side with him and you'll sink with him. Hear me? Speechless, Prendick watches Davis stumble back down the companionway. When he glances around he sees that both Montgomery and M are watching him silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick stands beside Montgomery on the quarterdeck, sta the awesome canopy of stars overhead. Montgomery passes him a smoldering joint.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Try some of this. Prendick waves it away.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I guarantee it. I grew it myself. Prendick takes it out of good manners but declines to smo it. He casts an eye over Montgomery's crumpled outfit, th unbuttoned Hawaiian shirt, bare feet, gold cross around h and a portion of a "Princeton Flag", tattooed on his ches

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: I haven't seen many Princeton tattoos.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's not the ivy league thing. Maybe that's why I did it. Montgomery looks at him, at the joint he's still holding.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Youâ€™re supposed to smoke that thing.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: (handing back the joint)  I remember a post game party at Harvard... I was taken suddenly drunk and I begged a Radcliff senior to carve her initials on my chest...

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: (brightly) Silver spooner, right?

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Well, I wasn't on a scholarship.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I can always tell. When we fished you out of the water, I could smell the money on you. Old money. The best kind! The nose knows... What did you study?

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: I got a degree in Humanities.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Humanities? Isn't that a licence to jerk off?

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: (Laughing) No. I had law school for that. Were you pre-med?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Biology. But that was a long time ago. He returns his attention to the sea.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Listen, you know... you saved my life...

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: (recoiling) I wouldn't get choked up about it.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, thanks. In any case I owe you my thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You don't owe me anything. You lucked out. I happened to be bored that day... looking for a little action. If I'd been feeling differently, you'd still be out there. I'd have stood here and waved you bye-bye.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: That's Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Believe whatever you've got to believe. I know you liberals need your little fairy tales. The two men look awkwardly away from each other.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: How did you happen to come out here?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You know, Eddie, I see us more like ships that pass in the night... not assholes who meet on a plane and tell each other the story of their lives.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Whatever. They lapse into awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Ever get yourself in real trouble? Montgomery gives him a look of anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: I helped draft the constitution for a small African nation. There was a coup... My staff and I were held hostage by a warlord. They shot one of us each day... Six people.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: But not you. You're a survivor.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: So far. But it's not over.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Sure it is. You'll be back in the States eating at Rodney Rockets and I'll be...

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: On your island Paradise.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: (smiles)  Paradise. That's Moreau's dream alright.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Moreau?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Man I work for. He once did for me what I did for you.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Pulled you out of a lifeboat?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Pulled me out and asked no questions. Anyway it's a boring little story and it's not like you and me are friends.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: We could be.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Wouldn't work.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Why's that?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: "Cause it's plain as the nose on your face that you think I'm crazy. Montgomery throws the joint into the sea and Prendick tur his eyes lighting now on the dark shape of Mâ€™Ling, who is over the taffrail. M'Ling turns towards him for an instan eyes glowing a pale luminous green in the light of the wh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a CLATTER of chains and a tortured, hydraulic WH followed by a scarcely human clamor of SHOUTS AND GRUNTS holding a frightened black leopard is hoisted skyward by rig of chain and cable, spinning in the air above the ris

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick wakes from an uneasy slumber and sits up in his rubbing his head, hearing HOARSE SHOUTING and PATTERING F overhead. As he gets to his feet there is a violent CREAK and the freighter lists uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Prendick comes up the ladder, the first thing he sees flushed sky and the rising sun over the broad back and re the Captain who stands, arms upraised, while above him th leopard spins in its cage.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: I don't give a shit! Off load all of them. Now, we'll have a clean ship! Prendick pushes past him and Davis turns with a start, st drunkenly at him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Hullo... why, it's Mister... Mister?

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Prendick.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Mr. Prawn-dick. You too. You're off my ship.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: (shocked) What do you mean? Off where?

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Where do you think? Back into the sea, that's where. Plenty of room for you there...

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, you can't...

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: (rolling his eyes) Oh Mother, here we go again. Mr. Prawn-dick's telling me what I can and can't do on my own ship. My own ship! Prendick looks past Davis and sees the island for the fir the jagged crest of a submerged mountain rising sheer fro ocean, its flanks covered with palm trees and dense scrub streamer of smoke rising from the treetops. A large motor launch lies under the lee of the freighter into this that the SAILORS are busy loading the last of t animals. M'Ling is already aboard the launch, helping three brutis BOATMEN with the staghounds while Montgomery stands on th talking with a NEWCOMER dressed in slightly grey white fl a battered Panama hat. The man's blazing eyes stern expr long grey hair and beard remind Prendick of a prophet out Old Testament.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Right this way, Mister!

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Fuck you. I'm not getting off here. Get away from me... He looks to Montgomery.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: (to the captain) Take him to Moresby, he'll pay you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: He can swim.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Look, I'll pay you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: I don't want your money... I piss on your money. Montgomery looks at Moreau who says nothing. He shouts ba Davis.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You'll have to take him. He can't come here.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: (desperate) Montgomery! For Christ's sake! Montgomery, already boarding the launch, nods towards Mor to indicate that he is powerless to intervene.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Eddie, I'm really sorry. Prendick glances around to see that he is loosely ringed belligerent-looking sailors. Two of the sailors take him arms and he begins to struggle.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: God damn it, get your hands off me! He pulls free from the sailors and hits one of them hard land him on the deck. Before he can go for the other one, more are on him. The decked sailor rises and hits him in stomach.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: Adios, Mr. Prawn-dick. Give my regards to the U.N... Great work you people are doing... I really hold you in awe.... Davis laughs maniacally as Prendick, doubled over, is hau struggling, to the gangway, but the launch is fully laden shoves off hastily. A broadening gap of green water appea Prendick who pushes back with all his strength now, tryin hold of the ship's rail. Stronger hands pry loose his fingers and he plunges from Bubbles explode around him and he goes under for a moment kicking his way back to the surface, gasping at the sudde the water. Above him he sees the steep side of the freighter, alread to come about, its engines throbbing, Davis standing at t still shouting unintelligible abuse at him. He turns and strikes out for the island, trying to distan from the ship's propellers. Then, with relief, he sees that the launch has turned bac him. As the launch draws nearer he is able to make out th of Moreau sitting cramped up with the dogs in the bow sta fixedly but not without kindness at him, M'Ling's face wa intently from the stern. The launch comes alongside him and the three brutish boat him awkwardly aboard where he crouches shivering, glancin uneasily at his rescuers. There is something strange about the features of the boat seem to be of some queer, brown-skinned race, their elfin peering out at him from beneath dirty turbans, lank black almost like horse hair framing their bright eyes. As he meets their gaze, first one and then the other turn him in a deferential manner. Moreau smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: (over the engines)  I couldn't let you drown, could I? I had no idea he'd really throw you in. Moreau turns away and looks to the crates. Looking up, Pr catches Montgomery's eyes as the launch comes about once starts back towards the island. He is serious, even grim.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: This wasn't my idea. Remember that. There is a soberness to Montgomery's voice that only deep Prendick's unease as he turns his attention towards the a beach. Prendick turns towards Moreau as if to speak, but the Doc him with a look, part smile, part warning, and Prendick s nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several LOCALS have assembled on the narrow jetty to meet launch, some of them hopping up and down in undisguised e One of the boathands throws a rope ashore and the launch engines and makes fast. Prendick steps ashore, looking dazedly about himself as t begin to unload, jabbering excitedly in their curious gut voices, Montgomery and Moreau shouting the occasional com the clamor of the staghounds. The island has the immediate lush beauty of all tropical islands. Birds call melodically from the surrounding lush vegetation, giving one the impression that life teems jus view. Prendick hears the SOUND of a grumbling engine and looks a battered military flatbed come bouncing down the narrow that connects the jetty with a fenced compound on the rid overlooking the beach. At the center of the compound is an old colonial-style bu a cluster of Nissan huts painted in a manner reminiscent camouflage or Aboriginal art. Beyond the roofs of the Nis Prendick can see the top of a radio mast and two rusting dishes. The main house is surrounded by a wide lawn enclosed by a fence. At the bottom of the lawn is a wooden rostrum over the compound gate and a flagpole from the top of which f emblem of the Tree of Life. M'Ling passes him now, bearing a packing case and talking enthusiastically with one of his fellow BEARERS, a man wi doglike features who wears a white jacket. He looks again to the beach and sees Moreau approaching h expression benign but formal.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: I regret we really have no facilities for guests, but we can feed you. You look like you could use some breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: I won't be here for long. I'm overdue as it is.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Yes, Montgomery told me you work for the UN... a lawyer. Fascinating. I know very little of law myself.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Once I call I'm sure they'll send a boat or a plane.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Yes, unfortunately at the moment our COMSAT equipment is down, but we're working on it. He looks absently out to sea.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Since the ozone layer started going, we've had communication problems. Something about magnetic storms... I'm a biologist, I don't really understand electronics. M'Ling returns now, having loaded his burden onto the par flatbed. He kneels beside Moreau.

dialogues.speaker: M'LING
dialogues.text: Father... I am so glad to see you again. Moreau pats M'Ling's arm and then incredibly the manserva the doctor's hand and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Yes, M'Ling. I'm glad to see you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father... I have seen the strangest things out there... So confusing...

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Yes, M'Ling, You must tell me all about it. The doctor glances back at Prendick, who is watching. To make the scene complete, in the background, a few of t strange men are holding a softball practise; one of them the ball to the others, who race around clumsily trying t it. Moreau's eyes wander across the curious islanders, fixing the man in the white coat.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: I'd better get busy. Azazello, see what Mr. Prendick would like for breakfast. (Glancing back at Prendick) Oh, and I have to ask that you restrict yourself to the main house. It's because of our insurance coverage. The people who fund us are afraid you might twist your ankle and sue us.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: (smiles) Unfortunately, it's a litigious world.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm sure you know all about that. We hear the crack of a bat and happy shouting.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Are these people native to this island? (off Moreau's look) They're very unusual looking.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Yes, many areas of the Pacific have very limited gene pools. Moreau moves off as Azazello approaches Prendick, awaitin order.

It is one of the rabbits from the bea has been savagely mutilated, the carcass glistening with Aissa glances back at Prendick, her face growing solemn.

dialogues.speaker: AISSA
dialogues.text: He's a bad one, that man. He's broken the Law. He's going back to the House of Pain. A staghound BAYS from somewhere behind them and Prendick her uneasily. Aissa darts forward once more, beckoning fo follow her. She sets off swiftly through the trees, moving at such a that Prendick has to struggle hard to keep up with her.

dialogues.speaker: AISSA
dialogues.text: Quicker, you have to run. At length they come to an open space in the forest and Ai once more to let him catch up. Ahead in the center of the surrounding the fungoid ruins of a huge, fallen tree are TAILED FIGURES, more like attenuated sloths walking on th legs than men, their naked bodies covered in a fine silve their long necks surmounted by odd chinless faces and eye dark pools of honey. They are engaged in picking some kind of fruit, pulling d prickly husks from the trees and scooping out the fleshy Prendick looks questioningly at Aissa.

dialogues.speaker: AISSA
dialogues.text: The Silent Ones. They were the first of his children but he didn't give them speech. Prendick is about to return his attention to the creature clearing when a FIGURE in a bright Hawaiian shirt steps f surrounding undergrowth.

dialogues.speaker: ASSASSIMON
dialogues.text: You! You! You! You! The furry figures in the glade take fright and go sloping the trees. Prendick turns to face the newcomer, a curious individual with long forearms and a heavy brow overshadow bright, curious eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ASSASSIMON
dialogues.text: You. In the boat.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Right... I came in the boat.

dialogues.speaker: ASSASSIMON
dialogues.text: You play ball with us now? Prendick glances awkwardly at the bat he's holding.

dialogues.speaker: ASSASSIMON
dialogues.text: Can you hit the ball?

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: (going with it)  Sure, I batted two ninety three when I played for the Cards.

dialogues.speaker: ASSASSIMON
dialogues.text: It's good. We need a power hitter very much to hit the long ball. (Smiling conspiratorially) I am the pitcher. My name is Assassimon.

dialogues.speaker: AISSA
dialogues.text: He's a Five Man like you! She takes Prendick's hand and holds it out so Assassimon Assassimon counts Prendick's fingers carefully, holding o for comparison.

dialogues.speaker: ASSASSIMON
dialogues.text: It is very good! We must tell Kiril! He swings around, gesturing for them to follow and then g trotting off, his hands hanging down and his jaw thrust f

dialogues.speaker: AISSA
dialogues.text: See, you're alright here. You'll be safe with me. Prendick turns to Aissa and takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drawing nearer, Prendick sees that a small village of woo shanties and lean-tos made from matted palm fans is hidde the volcanic boulders. Several of the villagers come sham their hovels to watch them as they enter the ravine and a deformed, dog-like children follow jibing at their heels. The walls of the ravine shelter are a wasp's nest of more mud-walled homes and it is into the doorway of one of tho Assassimon disappears. Prendick glances around, wrinkling his nose at the pungen The ground is covered with decaying fruit pulp and other the air here is thick with smoke. Something brushes his leg and he starts violently down to pinkish thing resembling a flayed looking child pawing at trousers. Assassimon reappears, and Aissa tugs him by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: AISSA
dialogues.text: Here. This is our home now.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Oh great. Looks like the Hospitality Suite at the Bronx Zoo. She gives him an uncomprehending, almost hurt look.

dialogues.speaker: AISSA
dialogues.text: What is wrong?

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: (melting) Nothing. It's fine. She leads him towards the shadowy aperture and he takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick finds himself in a semi-circular space shaped li half of a beehive. Rough vessels of lava and wood stand a floor and one on a rough stool. In the darkest corner of chamber sits a shapeless mass of darkness that GRUNTS as enters.

dialogues.speaker: KIRIL
dialogues.text: Hey! Assassimon stands in the dim light of the doorway and hol split coconut to Prendick as he crawls into the other cor crouch beside Aissa. The little pink Sloth Creature stand in from the aperture, and something else with a drab face bright eyes comes to stare over its shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: KIRIL
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: ASSASSIMON
dialogues.text: It is a man! Look, it is a man!

dialogues.speaker: KIRIL
dialogues.text: Shut up. Kiril pulls himself upright, his head brushing the ceilin him to hold his huge, bearish frame in a melancholic stoo He peers short-sightedly down at Prendick who looks him i in as friendly a manner as he can muster. Kiril rummages shadows beside his bed and produces a battered portable s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have batteries? I need the Energizer.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: No... I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: AISSA
dialogues.text: He's new. He came on the ship.

dialogues.speaker: KIRIL
dialogues.text: Then you must learn the Law.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: That's really not necessary. I'm a lawyer and I...

dialogues.speaker: KIRIL
dialogues.text: (dismissive) That way... Kiril turns and motions towards a passageway leading deep the hillside.

dialogues.speaker: KIRIL
dialogues.text: Through there...Go! Prendick starts forward with trepidation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Kiril showing the way, they enter a corridor that wi grows gradually brighter, letting out into a huge, natura lit by a fissure open to the sky. The galleries of the cave are lined with crouching FIGURE eyes glinting in the half light, their outlines made hazy greasy smoke rising from the embers of a fire on the floo Prendick sees now that the walls of the cave are covered elaborate paintings. Innumerable twisted stick figures da the rock faces, rising from four legs to two, from beast encircling on the far wall a huge rendition of the Tree o the spiralling ladder of the D.N.A. double helices. The bear man turns now towards Prendick, who stands awest

dialogues.speaker: KIRIL
dialogues.text: This is the House of the Law. I am the Keeper of the Way. Only a few can ever enter here. Kiril takes down a conch shell that hangs beside the ent placing it to his lips, blows a mighty BLAST, setting off MURMURING that ripples throughout the cavern. A FIGURE appears now before the painted helices, stepping shaft of light that falls from the crevice high above. A figure in a stained white suit and battered Panama hat wh holding a grisly fetish staff.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Moreau... He starts to raise the bat, but then sees that it is not after all. The suit is too filthy and the beard he now re made from tufts of dyed hair affixed to a painted wooden mask, however, fails to disguise the two huge ram horns t from the sides of this grotesque head.

dialogues.speaker: SAYER OF THE LAW
dialogues.text: Who is there?

dialogues.speaker: KIRIL
dialogues.text: A Five Man, from the sea! He's come to hear the Law! At this, a sudden clamoring of pipes and drums comes from gallery above and several of the shadowy figures closest turn towards Prendick, crowding around him, touching his clothes, taking him by the hands and dragging him further chamber. A corpulent SOW LADY, her heavy thighs painted with grey approaches him, draping a garland of wild flowers around She makes as if to embrace him, and he recoils in revulsi Aissa lashes out at her, forcing her to withdraw.

dialogues.speaker: AISSA
dialogues.text: Get away from him! He's mine! Prendick looks back at her uneasily, catching an unmistak gleam in her eyes. There is a lull in the clamoring and t of the Law calls attention by banging his fetish staff ag rocks.

dialogues.speaker: SAYER OF THE LAW
dialogues.text: Not to walk on all-fours; that is the Law. Prendick says nothing; Kiril nudges him firmly.

dialogues.speaker: KIRIL
dialogues.text: Say it.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KIRIL
dialogues.text: Repeat the law.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Not to walk on all-fours. (Then, after prompting from Kiril) That is the Law. The crowd echoes his words and the ceremony begins. The Sayer of the Law intones the mad litany, line by line crowd repeats it, swaying from side to side and beating t hands on their knees.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Not to walk on all-fours; that is the Law. Are we not men? Not to suck up drink; that is the Law. Are we not men? Not to eat flesh nor fish; that is the Law. Are we not men? Not to claw the bark of trees; that is the Law. Are we not men? Not to chase other men; that is the Law. Are we not men? Not to couple any which-way; that is the Law. Are we not men? Prendick is transfixed by this powerful and moving traves human ritual. He stares amazed as the crowd sways, faster faster. There is a loud MUSICAL PUNCTUATION from the uppe and the chanting swings to a new formula.

dialogues.speaker: SAYER OF THE LAW
dialogues.text: The punishments of those who break the Law are terrible. None escape.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: None escape. His is the House of Pain. His is the Hand that makes. His is the Hand that wounds. His is the Hand that heals. None escape! Assassimon comes forward, as if to confess to the congreg

dialogues.speaker: ASSASSIMON
dialogues.text: None escape! See, I did a wrong thing once, it was a little thing... I jabbered... I stopped talking. No one could understand me. Look! (He  holds out his hand.) I am burned, branded here on the hand. And now I talk! He is great! He is good!

dialogues.speaker: SAYER OF THE LAW
dialogues.text: Sooner or later, every one will want a thing that is bad. What you will want, we do not know. Some want to follow things that move, to watch and slink and spring, to kill and bite, bite deep and rich, sucking all the warm blood... It is bad. Not to chase other men; that is the Law. Are we not men? Not to eat flesh nor fish, never; that is the Law. Are we not men? To couple only with one; that is the Law. The congregation is hypnotized by the ritual of this.

dialogues.speaker: SAYER OF THE LAW
dialogues.text: Some go scratching at the graves of the dead, some go fighting with foreheads or claws, some bite suddenly without or warning, some go snuffing at the earth, some love uncleanness, some make wild and random fornications every which-way...it is bad.

dialogues.speaker: ASSASSIMON
dialogues.text: None escape! Suddenly, there the SOUND OF GUNFIRE is heard outside. A starts amongst those assembled and above their voices Pre hears the distant BAYING of staghounds.

dialogues.speaker: ASSASSIMON
dialogues.text: He's coming! Heâ€™s coming! There is a cacophonic CLASH OF PERCUSSION from the upper and the entire congregation starts towards the door at on furry tumult of struggling, misshapen forms, almost tramp Prendick underfoot. He swiftly loses sight of Kiril and Aissa, allowing the c suck him towards the door, hearing now the SOUND of the l come from somewhere outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick bursts blinking into the daylight, the last stra the congregation still lurching past him to join the crow gathering at the mouth of the canyon. Prendick pushes through them, peering over the hunched s and pointed ears to see a nightmarish procession approach It is led by Moreau, cantering astride the horse, his awf shadowed by the brim of his Panama hat, a bullwhip in his hunting rifle in a scabbard, the villagers supplicating t before him, throwing dust over their heads and laying pal before the horse's hooves as he rides into the settlement is flanked by a retinue of DOG MEN who carry whips as wel M'Ling, Waggdi and Azazello, who control the leashes of t snarling staghounds. Montgomery walks sullenly behind them, a gun in one hand loud hailer in the other. Prendick turns to see that his way back through the canyo blocked by more of the villagers. He ducks down, trying t himself in the crowd. Beyond the huts the wall of the rainforest is tantalizing yet hopelessly far away. Moreau is almost parallel with h his eyes like splinters of ice as he surveys the crowd. B Montgomery raises the loud hailer.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I know he's in there. Better give him up. I mean now!

dialogues.speaker: SAYER OF THE LAW
dialogues.text: Evil is he who breaks the Law!

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: And you know what happens when you break the law, don't you? You shaggy little fucker...

dialogues.speaker: ALL, (CHORUS)
dialogues.text: Back to the House of Pain! Back to the House of Pain, Master!

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You got it, boys and girls... back to the House of Pain. Come on now. Where is he? The villagers slowly turn their snouts towards Prendick w to make a run for it, dashing his shoulder into one clums and flinging him forward into another. The little pink Sloth Creature grasps at his legs and he savage blow to its face with the baseball bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks with incredible severity at Aissa. She looks imp back.

dialogues.speaker: AISSA
dialogues.text: Father, please... Moreau smiles tenderly at her, then turns sharply away. Hands clutch at Prendick. He pitches headlong through the tackles Montgomery, both of them going down almost beneat horse's hooves, grappling desperately for the gun.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: God, Eddie, you're turning into a real pain in the ass. We just want to... Prendick strikes him on the jaw and, wrestling his finger trigger guard, regains his feet just as the Dog Men come to him, brandishing their cattle prods. He raises the gun round into the air.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Back, You fucking freaks! He fires another round and Moreau's horse panics, rearing dangerously and causing the Dog Men to scatter. Prendick turns and makes a break for it, sprinting across patch towards the shelter of the trees, where he turns an another shot, while Moreau struggles to get his horse bac control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick runs full tilt through the undergrowth, the auto clutched in one hand, the air behind him filled with thre cries and the baying of staghounds. He zig-zags through t pausing and changing course as he hears BRANCHES CRACKING then turning again as he hears Moreau and Montgomery SHOU somewhere behind him and the NEIGHING of the horse. Some of the islanders are ROARING AND SCREAMING now like prey as they hurl themselves after him through the foliag primitive cudgels clasped in their hands. As Prendick forces his way through the thick undergrowth forest, shadow figures brachiate through the trees above WHOOPING, HOWLING, GIBBON-LIKE BEAST MEN quickly overtake cut off his escape, menacing him from the canopy above. Prendick turns and fights through a tangled thicket of t toward a break in the trees. Breaking from the undergrowth which tears at his clothes, reaches the edge of a narrow gully and falls headlong int steaming waters of a murky, sulphurous stream. The gun fa the muck. The sound of the pursuing dogs grows louder as his feet. Gasping with pain as the steaming mud clings to flesh. Shoving his hands into the sulfureous mud to find the gun forced to withdraw them quickly before they are cooked by viscous, almost boiling water. Suddenly, a HYENA-SWINE MA from the surrounding brush and, seeing Prendick, gives a As the creature lunges into the mud Prendick stumbles awa bleeding profusely now from a wound in his scalp. The YELPING of the dogs and Dogmen and a CHATTERING AND A followed by the CRACK of a whip and VOICES. Prendick sets off again, splashing ankle deep through the water, crying out to himself as he runs, seeing the blue the ocean now through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick splashes across the delta and does not stop runn he is up to his knees in salt water, staring out at the s and the unreachable horizon. He turns westward, stumbling water's edge. Then, suddenly, far in front of him, he sees figures emer the rainforest. Moreau on his horse, then Montgomery, the the Dog Men with their snapping charges. They see him and advancing. Prendick starts to turn only to see a posse of villagers from the tree line behind him to cut him off. He looks towards the horizon once more and, having nowher left, wades straight out into the water. Moreau addresses him from the water's edge. Aissa stands beside him, frightened and confused.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Mr. Prendick, please...There's no escape from here. His eyes wander over the massed ranks, over Aissa and M' Waggdi and Azazello and further up the beach Assassimon, the others.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: They were men... But you've mutilated them, made slaves of them.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: That's not it at all. You've got it wrong. Prendick shouts at the gathering.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Listen! There's a hundred of you, and two of them! You have nothing to fear from them. You don't need to obey!

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Prendick! The islanders seem puzzled, staring wonderingly at Prendi edge closer to the tide line and Moreau cracks his whip, them to retreat once more.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: These men aren't gods! You have the power to free yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Back off, man. Don't start something that might end in tears. Moreau moves his horse forward. When he is near Prendick indicates the rifle in its saddle scabbard.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Mr. Prendick, this rifle is loaded. Please, take it. Prendick hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Take the rifle and put your mind at ease. We are not the enemy. It mustn't appear that there's conflict between us. Cautiously, Prendick moves towards him and slips the rifl scabbard. He aims it at Moreau who nudges his horse close

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering fiercely) Those are not men. Do you understand me? They're Chromatic hybrids... experiments in a humanizing process. Don't excite them or it could be bad for all of us.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: They're animals?

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Please, Mr. Prendick, they're not without sensitivity. Montgomery moves towards them; Prendick swings the rifle them both, but he comes slowly closer.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Eddie, we hunted you for your own good. This island is full of... unstable phenomena.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: You might not have survived the night.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: That woman I saw on the operating table...

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: You didn't see a woman. What you saw was not a human. You're certainly entitled to ethical reservations about our research, but at least hear us out.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: C'mon Eddie, stop pointing that thing at my head.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: We mean you no harm. Our only intention is to get you safely on your way.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Oh, right... but I suppose the COMSAT equipment is still down.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Yes, it is down. Do you want to know the reason? There's been a nuclear exchange between India and Pakistan. We heard it on the short wave radio.  Prendick is stricken.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: All COMSAT communication is restricted to military usage. Prendick looks away at the distant sea, trying to imagine beyond the island.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: A war?

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: So far it's only the rumble of a distant storm, but it brings a new imperative to our survival... to the work we do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moreau gingerly lifts the vinyl sheet, and Prendick peers distaste bordering on revulsion at the mutilated body str the operating table. The automatic is still clutched in h Moreau watches him cooly.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: You tell me, is that human?

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: I don't know what she is.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Actually, she's a genetic hybrid. We call them Chimaeras. Prendick looks uncomprehendingly at him.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Very poetic. What does it mean?

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Animals, engineered in the image of humans.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: I've always heard you people are desperate for grant money. But animals into humans, don't you think that's a reach? Moreau draws the sheet over the woman's remains again and away from the operating table; Prendick follows.  Prendick Prendick

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: If I'm to to succeed at improving mandkind, then what I create must have human form.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: You'll only succeed in filling tabloid headlines. There's no market for home made people. Creating these things is immoral.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: War and death generated by the twisted laws of nations... is that the moral highground? has no response. Moreau rubs his eyes wearily.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: I can't believe I'm having to explain myself like this. Montgomery told me what you did, I hoped you believed that humanity can be improved?

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: I don't see this as improving it.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Why not? I've improved other living things... created wheat that grows in the Sahara, other plants that kill and eat their own predators. Everything has to start with basics, like creating a new race without the evil or venality of our species.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: This half dissected thing was sacrificed to that goal?

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Growth must be accelerated, centuries of evolution compressed into minutes, the process takes its toll on the organism.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: And the screams?

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Deliberate pain serves only as a training tool. It will fall away from us one day, along with it's depraved twin, pleasure. gives him a sharp look.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Why do you doubt me, Mr. Prendick, because you failed improve humanity with laws?

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: I only set out to solve a few local problems. I leave improvements on the human race to a higher authority.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: I choose to believe that authority works through me... pushes me to finish my work. Moreau stops by the pen that holds the black leopard from The animal is comatose now, its belly already hideously d kept alive only by nutrients fed directly into its veins of drips.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: I chose this creature for its strength to withstand the rigors of accelerated fetal growth.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: It's not doing well. Maybe you chose wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: She's being devoured by a fetus growing at over fifty times the normal rate. Her life will end to give new life. That seems cruel to you doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Yes, it does.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: And to me. But I have no choice. My own clock runs at accelerated speed. I must finish before I'm finished. (passionately) And I'm close... I'm very close...She's going to me my breakthrough. I know it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moreau dons a curious pair of goggles. He hands a pair t

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Do you know the term nanotechnology?

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: I know enough Greek to know nano means small.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Very small... It involves mechanically shifting things on a molecular level. Moreau demonstrates the laboratory's centerpiece, a combi and electron microscope, its needle thin blue beam focuse on a tiny slide, its glow bathing the room in an eerie bl luminescence.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Nanotechnology enables us to isolate and transfer specific gene sequences. Then through artificial insemination and surrogacy we can create hybrids that would be impossible in conventional crossbreeding. The beam of the laser moves down into a subatomic world t suddenly ablaze with light. Rising before them are the sp helices of the DNA molecule, the fundamental building blo spinning in the laser's glare.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: My work will form the basis of a renaissance in genetic engineering that will transform the new century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are watching the early days of the experiment. Moreau, now, oversees the work of a chain-smoking behaviorist.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: I wonâ€™t bore you with our early efforts. Basically we moved through herbivores to carnivores to capitalize on the intelligence that goes with predation. Then, taking a gorilla, I made my first "Man". The videotape CUTS to a shaky handheld SHOT of a squat, d skinned APE MAN walking on the front lawn, holding hands Moreau.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Everything our race has forgotten is being found again, here on this island as if for the very first time. That's Prima, our first real success... We took him from the surrogate mother at birth and raised him here in the compound. Dr. Conway was with me then. Prendick watches now as an attractive chain-smoking woman CONWAY, submits Prima to a battery of intelligence tests, flashcards, and reading-readiness tests.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: By the age of five, Prima could speak English at least as well as the average human child of the same age. Conway was incredibly gifted in communicating with him. Dr. Conway holds up a drawing of a suburban street. All a normal in the picture save for the presence of a car with wheels and an elegant-looking woman who is strolling down sidewalk with a tiger on a leash.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CONWAY, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Now, Prima, can you see anything wrong with this picture? Prima scratches his head.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CONWAY, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Come on, Prima. Big thinks, baby. Big thinks. Prima extends his hand to touch the square wheel but igno the tiger.

dialogues.speaker: PRIMA, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Car?

dialogues.speaker: DR. CONWAY, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Ver-ry good! She makes a mark in her notebook, the shadow of a frown c her face.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: It's impossible, really, to gauge non-human intelligence by human standards. Moreau's eyes shine with intense feeling as he watches Co the screen.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Conway worked tirelessly with them. She was so dedicated... inspired. Dr. Conway produces another drawing, a depiction of sever objects, a house, a chair, a tree, a flower and a hat.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CONWAY, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Now, Prima, which one do you go to when there's a storm? When it's wet and raining?

dialogues.speaker: PRIMA, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Tree. He touches the drawing and Dr. Conway shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CONWAY, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: No, Prima. You go to the house when it rains. Prima frowns and bows his head, his shoulders hunched.

dialogues.speaker: PRIMA, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Damn me good. Prima takes one of Dr. Conwayâ€™s cigarettes and lights it nervously as though afraid it might be taken from him.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Today the population of our island stands at more than sixty. That's not counting the creatures without human speech or form. Altogether I've made more than a hundred and twenty, some had to be destroyed. Prendick reacts to this word.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: What happened to Dr. Conway?

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: Dr. Conway died. The video images give way to scenes of carnage, the labor floor awash with blood.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU
dialogues.text: (with difficulty) An experiment that got out of control. A thing with a human face that moved like a snake. Incredibly strong, enraged by the pain of its creation... It killed her here, then escaped. We cornered it and destroyed it in the northern part of the island. In the chaos other creatures  escaped as well. Regrettably, there was some hybridization beyond my control. Moreau reaches for the remote control and stops the tape.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU

dialogues.text: I know, Prendick. I know what is happening to me... I can feel it.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: AISSA
dialogues.text: Yes, it matters.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: There's a way to fix it, in your father's notes. I'll find it. We'll bring you back. Now, go to the house. Get whatever you need to take.

dialogues.speaker: AISSA
dialogues.text: (apprehensive) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: There's something I have to do. He turns to address the assembly.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Children of the Law! Listen to me! The Master has left a task for you! He turns towards the laboratory, motioning for the Beast follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick strides down the aisleway between the cages, Kir Sayer of the Law leading the remnants of the Beast People him.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Empty the cages! Free all of them! The Beast Folk go to work at once, scooping rabbits from hutches, dogs and cats and monkeys from their cages. Pren stalks slowly through the devastated laboratory, flipping switch on a Nagra as he passes, hearing Moreau's VOICE, n more now than a magnetic ghost.

dialogues.speaker: MOREAU'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Systolic pressure 3.2. Diastolic pressure up to 4. Pulmonary pressure stands at 5.8. Prendick stops at the shelf, lifting Moreau's black book. It falls open in his hands and he casts an eye over the c equations contained there, an escaped monkey scampering u to perch on his shoulder, mimicking his puzzlement at Mor notes. Behind him, the Sayer of the Law opens the incubators one handing out the mewling mutant infants to a line of islan who bear them out into the safety of the orange night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The awesome SOUND of the Jimi Hendrix Experience throbbin tinny set of speakers, supplemented by a line of DRUMMING Folk, tangling with the SOUNDTRACK of "King Kong" that is on a screen set before the CD-ROM projector that has been for a rapt, tripped-out animal audience. A great bonfire sparks into the sky farther up the beach, ringed by furio dancing creatures. Beside the bonfire, an axe-wielding Do chopping up the remains of the beached motor launch and f them into the flames. Montgomery stands near the fire, burning of the boat, sup the ritual a garland of flowers around his neck and a joi dangling from his lower lip. The Sloth Creature drags at the hem of his coat and he smiles sadly, turning out his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All gone. See. All tapped out. We're in the same boat now, (points to the burning launch) and there it is right there! Up the creek without a paddle. Any of you ever hear that expression? He starts to get undressed, throwing his clothes to the B People who grab at them eagerly, fighting for possession more treasured articles. Montgomery lifts his head up and shouts.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: How do you like this, Moreau? Isn't this some wild shit! The Beast People press tighter around him, reaching out t his pale skin. He giggles, looking up at the stars.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: All flesh is grass, boys and girls. You blink and it's all gone... He grabs an already disheveled Beast Woman and breaks int demented, frenzied and very dirty boogie. The flatbed goes rumbling past, headlights blazing, circl dangerously close to the fire, joyriding through the nigh nowhere, M'Ling at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Azazello unbolts the gun locker and opens it up to displa contents to his fellow conspirators: the Hyena-Swine, a b black Boar Man and a pair of the surviving Dog Men who st waiter's coats. Behind them, the rest of the room is alre chaos as several of the Beast People root through Moreau' flinging the books from the shelves, the unleashed parrot wildly around their heads. The Hyena-Swine hefts a Kalash eyes glowing in anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: HYENA- SWINE
dialogues.text: Now we have the fire that kills. Now we are Gods! Azazello weighs a hand grenade in his palm, his face crac terrible, gap-toothed grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aissa crosses the hallway on her way to her room. There is a sudden rattle of automatic GUNFIRE followed by peal of raucous LAUGHTER from the direction of the study stiffens, drawing back against the wall with a HISS. Azazello appears now in the study door, clutching a bottl brandy, the other two Dog Men following him at a pace.

dialogues.speaker: AZAZELLO
dialogues.text: Trip-trap, trip-trap... and where are you going in the woods today, little girl? Aissa edges towards the door but the Dog Men cut her off.

dialogues.speaker: AZAZELLO
dialogues.text: Looking for your five-finger man? He can't help you. There are no masters anymore. He advances and she raises a hand as if to strike him. He extend from her fingertips and her eyes glint in the fire hair on her back raises as she emits a long catlike hiss.

dialogues.speaker: AZAZELLO
dialogues.text: Nicely now little kitten-Aissa or I'll hurt you. Remember how the master hurt me? Oh, how he whipped me. He gives an oily CHUCKLE, his voice becoming a growl.

dialogues.speaker: AZAZELLO
dialogues.text: But he spared your soft skin. One of the Dog Men reaches out to grab her hair and she b teeth in a feral snarl. Lashing out at Azazello, her claw face nearly blinding him. Azazello stumbles back with a canine yelp, pawing at his other two Dog Men lunge at her, the blood lust rising in eyes. Aissa turns. Finding no way out of the room she leaps tow curtains. Locking her claws in the heavy material, she sc toward the valence while the Dog Men try to grab her and back. She tries to reach the large chandelier, but the curtain and valence give way and she falls back toward the floor; in mid- fall she twists catlike to land on all fours ina crouch. A low threatening growl boils from her throat as she face and the Dog Men, holding them at bay like a cornered cat maneuver cautiously to surround her. Suddenly, with a shriek she springs at Azazello. Her claw with lightening speed at his face while he staggers back. goes into his coat and he pulls an automatic. As Aissa claws for his throat, he shoots her at zero rang is a deafening concussion. Her eyes widen, revealing the of her rage as she convulses with the impact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remainder of the Beast People, standing before the bl pyre, turn as a burst of gunfire shatters the night. The Hyena-Swine stands in the doorway of the big house, b his Kalashnikov. As the congregation watches he fires a s burst at the stars.

dialogues.speaker: HYENA- SWINE
dialogues.text: Bow to me! I send the fire that kills. He squeezes off another burst for effect and several of t People drop to their knees. Kiril moves forward pulling t groveling figures back to their feet by the scruffs of th

dialogues.speaker: HYENA- SWINE
dialogues.text: Bow to me!

dialogues.speaker: KIRIL
dialogues.text: Who are you that I should bow to you? We are brothers. He turns to face the congregation.

dialogues.speaker: KIRIL
dialogues.text: Children of the Law, we must stand firm. We must uphold the Law and work together now. We must rule with love, not hate. We are brothers, all of us. The Hyena-Swine switches the Kalashnikov onto single fire shoots Kiril in the back. He pitches forward.  The congregation GASPS. The Hyena-Swine CHUCKLES, slides in a new banana clip. Some of the Beast People start to shout now, falling to their knees and wringing their hands.

dialogues.speaker: SAYER OF THE LAW
dialogues.text: No! This is wrong! You are breaking the Law!

dialogues.speaker: HYENA- SWINE
dialogues.text: If It Feels Good, Do It, is the Law! Montgomery told me so.

dialogues.speaker: SAYER OF THE LAW
dialogues.text: We must have Laws! We are not animals!

dialogues.speaker: HYENA- SWINE
dialogues.text: Law no more!

dialogues.speaker: SAYER OF THE LAW
dialogues.text: (with incredible feeling) Are we not men? The Hyena-Swine laughs, switches his Kalashnikov onto ful empties its magazine into the crowd, the Boar Man at his excitedly joining in the massacre with his own AK-47. All are still standing are caught in a withering rain of bull bodies jerking in the glow of the funeral pyre. The Sayer of the Law is among the first to fall, his mask by a bullet between the eyes. A spray of bullets punch into fuel cans stockpiled in the rivulet of gasoline creeps away, leading back towards the house. The Hyena-Swine is laughing and laughing, the gun growing his hands, fire leaping in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick takes a crowbar to a metal file and rips it open through the papers and finds several note books. He begin frantically flipping through them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things have started to slip at the beach party. Several of the Beast Folk lie shaking on the sand, gripp epileptic seizures, while one of the Cat People has torn own eyes and sits screaming beside the projector. The fla stuck in the sand, smoke pouring out of it, M'Ling limpin towards the fire in open embarrassment. Montgomery stands naked in the midst of the admiring Chim staring back towards the big house, his attention drawn b sound of GUNFIRE.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: What the fuck now...?

dialogues.speaker: M'LING
dialogues.text: Master! M'Ling steps towards Montgomery but the Bison Man cuts hi striking the Dog Man over the head with an empty bottle.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: No! Don't hurt him! He makes as if to go to M'Ling's assistance, but the Biso blocks his way.

dialogues.speaker: BISON MAN
dialogues.text: No more Masters! Montgomery turns to see the other Beast Folk crowding in awful hunger flaring in their eyes. A low growl ripples a beach, rising into a snarl of rage.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Hey I come on, man, lighten up... This is supposed to be a party! The little pink Sloth thing steps suddenly forward and sh Montgomery in the chest with his own automatic. He staggers backwards, staring in disbelief at the pucker his breastbone.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Shit! You... You were always such a sweet little fucker, too... Jesus... Thanks a lot... He falls against the CD-ROM projector and the image goes distortion. He slips to his knees and, with a SHRIEK, the Beast Peopl upon him, ripping and ravaging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick is edging towards the door Moreau's black book c his chest, his automatic in his hand when the Hyena-Swine Boar Man burst into the room, levelling their rifles. He the cover of the overturned operating table, a bullet mea heart hitting instead in the leather cover of Moreau's jo He hugs the ground, covering his head as the renegades pu after round into the laboratory, shattering the overhead laboratory equipment. The big tank cracks and comes apart, spilling a wave of w amniotic fluid across the floor, the gilled mutations flo writhing amidst the broken glass. The Hyena-Swine pauses to reload, padding on the tips of towards Prendick's hiding place, its teeth bared.

dialogues.speaker: HYENA- SWINE
dialogues.text: Come out and face me! Let us see who is the Master, now! Prendick crawls gasping for the safety of the ruined bank visual equipment, prompting a hysterical burst of GUNFIRE Hyena-Swine. Prendick cringes, bullets RICOCHETING and sparking all ar There follows another lull as the Hyena-Swine fumbles for clip. dialogues.speaker: MOREAU'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Diastolic pressure up to 4. Pulmonary pressure stands at 5.8. Heartbeat irregular. The Boar Man freezes, turning to the Hyena-Swine.

dialogues.speaker: HYENA- SWINE
dialogues.text: No! It is a trick! He is dead! We killed him! He opens fire once more but Prendick has already ducked s of sight, crouching behind a console and pulling on a pai goggles. The Hyena-Swine glances about himself uneasily, then as forward, Prendick reaches out and throws the switch on th its light filling the room with a brilliant blue-green gl renegades yell, trying to cover their eyes as Prendick sp from behind the console, shooting the Boar Man in the thr Boar Man topples backwards. The Hyena-Swine screams, blindly loosing a burst of gunfi Prendick's direction. One of the bullets damages the lase housing and Prendick decides to take a chance, diving acr room towards the door and tilting the laser from its bear passes.
