Then Prendick shoots him in the stomach and he goes down, amidst the tendrils of the tank dwellers, still kicking a screaming, one paw grasping for a hand grenade. Prendick takes a step back as the Hyena-Swine pulls the p draws back his arm to pitch the grenade, but then one of tentacles coils around his wrist and holds it tight. Pren for the door. The Hyena-Swine's last shriek of pain and fear is cut sho ear-splitting CONCUSSION and the laboratory is torn apart of fire and flying shrapnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick steps over the mound of corpses, eyes narrowed a smoke, the gun in one hand, Moreau's black book in the ot

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Aissa! He scans the faces of the dead but does not see her among The flames are spreading now from the blazing laboratory other huts, climbing towards the radio mast. Up ahead, th house is already on fire and Prendick battles his way tow door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick stumbles coughing through the doorway, one arm r protect his face from its burning frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aissa! Then his eyes to adjust to the smoke-filled room and what seems to rob him of what little sanity he has left. Aissa's body lies on the dining table, her entire torso a wound, Azazello and the Dog Men sitting around her, as if feed on her flesh. Prendick reacts with a bellow of primal rage. He raises h blasts at the Dog Men. One is struck in the head. Another when he runs for the door. Wounded, he runs yelping to a where other shots bring him down. Prendick turns the gun on Azazello who glares at him with menace. He pulls the trigger but the chamber CLICKS on em Azazello turns with a SHRIEK and throws himself through t rear window, fleeing YELPING into the night. Prendick stands over Aissa, beyond grief, beyond any emot Taking the compass from her fingers, he holds her hand, a flames move across the walls around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of EXPLOSIONS rip through the enclosure, engulfi house, the singing aloes rising screaming in tongues of l flame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick stands watching the rising sun. He seems transfo grief and by his exposure to horror. The big house is bur behind him. Montgomery's remains are at his feet covered blood-soaked blanket. M'Ling kneels beside him, weeping.

dialogues.speaker: M'LING
dialogues.text: They are mad! They are fools! They say there is no Law. No Master. No whips. No House of Pain anymore. We love the Law and will keep it now but there is no more pain, no more whips forever again, they say. But I know, Master, I know. You still live. You have walked in the sea and lived. Prendick pats M'Ling's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good man, M'Ling.

dialogues.speaker: M'LING
dialogues.text: You will kill them all? Prendick turns his eyes towards the burning flatbed and t remnants of the motor launch. There are bodies strewn all beach.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: No. Not all.

dialogues.speaker: M'LING
dialogues.text: The Master's will is sweet. Behind them the radio mast collapses, sending a flurry of climbing into the heavens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of the HORN rises once more into the morning ai Prendick, M'Ling, Assassimon and two of the remaining eld on the rostrum, Azazello bound and kneeling at their feet The rest of the islanders gather uneasily before them. Th fewer than thirty of them left.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Heâ€™s not dead! He's speaking to me right now! The House of Pain will be back again! You can't see the Master, but he's watching everything you do!

dialogues.speaker: M'LING
dialogues.text: True! True! The Fox Lady steps forward, cradling one of the children incubators.

dialogues.speaker: FOX LADY
dialogues.text: The Man Who Walks in the Sea now leads.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: The Master speaks through me. For those who break the Law!

dialogues.speaker: ASSASSIMON
dialogues.text: Back to the House of Pain! Back to the House of Pain! The congregation takes up the chant, their voices swelli Prendick stares in cold fury as Azazello slinks forward c and very frightened. He kneels before Prendick, who touch head with barely-controlled hatred.

dialogues.speaker: ALL, (CHORUS)
dialogues.text: Back to the House of Pain! Back to the House of Pain!

dialogues.speaker: AZAZELLO
dialogues.text: (looking imploringly at Prendick) Back to the House of Pain! Back to the House of Pain! He tries to lick Prendick's hand. Prendick puts the gun t Azazello's head and the Dog Man whimpers. The gun jumps, spitting fire, and Azazello falls, blood j from his temple. The audience falls silent.

dialogues.speaker: FOX LADY
dialogues.text: The gun has spoken! It is good! They fall into a new rhythm, their chant rising and risin

dialogues.speaker: ALL, (CHORUS)
dialogues.text: His is the hand that wounds! His is the hand that heals! His is the lightning flash! His is the deep salt sea! Prendick stands looking out over them, Moreau's book stil under his arm, the gun clenched in his free hand. It's as he's staring at something a thousand miles away, as tears down his cheeks. The crowd bows down, the sky filled with black smoke risi the ruins behind them, the emblem of the Tree of Life sti fluttering from the flagpole above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick stands in the shaft of light at the center of th the fetish staff in his hands, leading the chanting congr His hair and beard have grown long and wild now, his and clothes are embroidered with bones and tassels, face beda paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After that day I became the Sayer of the Law. Every day for nine months I stood in front of the Tree of Life and talked to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick is observing the moon through a cleft in the roc marking the lunar calendar painted on the cavern wall.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I rewrote the Law and tried to teach them new ways to survive on their own. The Law I gave them was the Law I dreamed of as a boy, that had made me want to be a lawyer, a Law that never really existed anywhere in the real world, except here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick stands thigh deep in the river teaching M'Ling a others the finer points of spear fishing, a lesson interr two of the onlookers start to squabble over a particularl looking barbel.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I taught them all I could, but day by day the animal returned to take over that which was human. Like it always has and always will. Like Moreau said it would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick, M'Ling and several others huddle beneath a fan palm leaves, sheltering from a torrential downpour.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: About thirty of them had survived and eight of those were dead by the end of the hurricane season, most from untreatable illnesses caused by their genetic disorders. I knew that if Aissa had lived she would have shared their fate, but that didn't take the pain away. By the time the trade winds blew again from the west, only M'Ling and Assassimon still clung to the power of speech, and were able to help me in my work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moreau's horse has been employed in dragging logs down fr rainforest to where M'Ling and Prendick are shaping them makeshift axes. Assassimon sits nearby, emptying barrels of diesel into t There follows a MONTAGE of activity as the raft slowly ta Assassimon rigging its sails as it lies at berth next to while Prendick and M'Ling load it with supplies.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: I'll be back with help. Give me three months.

dialogues.speaker: M'LING
dialogues.text: It is good. Go well, Master.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Go well yourself, M'Ling. Good M'Ling. He embraces M'Ling. The Dog Man fawns upon him, whimperin pulls away and, clambering aboard the raft, makes ready a off. Assassimon comes running down the jetty, shouting at the lungs.

dialogues.speaker: ASSASSIMON
dialogues.text: He is going! He is good! He is going! He is great! Prendick strikes an offshore current, unfurling a bright homespun from the mast, a gaudy representation of The Tre painted in its center. The wind fills the sail and he adj tillers, turning the raft's prow towards the open sea. M'Ling sits down, his big feet dangling over the edge of looking a little dejected, watching until Prendick is far

dialogues.speaker: M'LING
dialogues.text: We must read. We must keep speech for his return. Then he lifts a battered copy of Alice in Wonderland and read aloud once more while Assassimon, hopping from foot pretends to mouth the words over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads, haltingly) "Humpty Dumpty sat on a wall: Humpty Dumpty had a great fall. All the King's horses and all the King's men. Couldn't put Humpty Dumpty together again." M'Ling's voice falters, tapering off into a bestial whimp He sits for a long while in silence, the book sagging in watching the sail of Prendick's raft until it has disappe sight.

dialogues.speaker: THE DISC OF THE SUN
dialogues.text: A dazzling, overexposed white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick lies on his back on the raft, the sail flapping now; his face raw and blistered from the sun. His head sw the rise and fall of the ocean and all the horizon seems with him, the earth and sky and the shining crack that se them. A dark smudge appears on the horizon. Dancing. Drawing ne closes his eyes. When he opens his eyes again he sees the side of a freigh looming over him, a row of figures gathered at the rail, silhouetted against the sun. Hands lift him now. Twisted, misshapen hands tipped with nails. His eyes focus on his rescuers and he sees the intent fac beasts of prey glaring down at him, their faces snoutish porcine, back covered with a sickly pink skin, their lips from yellowed teeth. He looks at them, completely blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick blinks, opening his eyes to find that he is sti on his chair in Dr. Murnau's office, the beasts have beco CHIEF DOCTOR and two of the staff psychiatrists, DR. WIEN MOCH, sitting facing him. He is clean shaven now and is w brand new suit and tie.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I'm glad we're in agreement. You finally understand you've been suffering an acute form of post-traumatic stress disorder brought on by the plane crash and your terrible ordeal at sea... You should be able to gradually unlock the memory of what really happened to you during that lost year.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: I have. I see that nothing much happened at all. I was simply adrift.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MOCH
dialogues.text: Perhaps as a young man you read about the real Doctor Moreau, who won Nobel Prize in 1989. The controversy surrounding his work could have been incorporated into your fantasies. Prendick smiles, nods.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: So I guess now it's on with my life.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: You've come a very long way.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: Thank you, Gentlemen. Thank you all, for everything. He stands, folding his coat over his arm. When he looks b doctors, however, it is to find them transformed into sca carrion birds staring hungrily at him across the desktop vulpine, bespectacled eyes, their dark wings stirring threateningly. He maintains his smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prendick stands on the corner of a busy city street, his folded over his arm, staring at the hubbub of life that s him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was released from the hospital in October 2010. The world hadn't come to an end, although there had been a nuclear exchange. Everything else, it seems, had been a symptom of my psychosis. We see the crowded street now through Prendick's eyes. Weary DEER MEN and CATTLE PEOPLE shambling past him with eyes, dripping blood, OLD PEOPLE, bent and dull murmuring themselves, prowling WOMEN mewing after him and dancing p jibing MONKEY CHILDREN skipping through a gridlocked traf barking CANINE MOTORISTS, belligerent PORCINE TRAFFIC POL to maintain order. Prendick turns now, seeing his own ref a shop window, the reflection of a rather melancholy-look sheepdog lost that has its flock, its eyes tired and lone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fire is low on the hearth. Prendick sits hunched in t darkness, the loaded gun still cradled in his hands, fini his final message running through the Nagra, a dog barkin distance. Moreau's notebook lies open on the table before him, a re of Draper's "Lament for Icarus" tacked on the wall behind over the desk, on crumpled pieces of paper, are sketches Tree of Life.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: On the island, I had thought that Moreau was the loneliest man on the earth. But that was before I became what I've become... I've spent my time in reading, and studying biochemistry only to realize that what Moreau did was in fact possible. What happened can't be dismissed as a nightmare. So I've had no choice but to live alone with the horrible truth. Prendick raises the gun, closing his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (haltingly) Now I find there is simply no way to bear the loneliness. In the near background we hear the barking of a dog. Prendick squeezes his eyelids shut, trying to blot out t He draws the hammer back with an audible click. Suddenly, the sound of a pair of paws hitting the pane of glass in door. The barking is now very loud, almost in the room. Prendick opens his eyes once more. The barking goes on. I strange, pleading quality. Prendick lowers the gun and looks toward the door. The dog is looking in. It sees him and barks with sudden recognition. Prendick can't avoid the animal. He rises an paws wildly at the doorpanel with obvious joy at his appr Prendick tries to muster a stern look.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: I locked you out for a reason. I can't very well kill myself with you pestering me. The dog barks imploring, then looks at Prendick and cocks He whympers for Prendick's affection.

dialogues.speaker: PRENDICK
dialogues.text: What? You'd miss me? The dog responds with a short, decisive bark. Prendick steps to the door and opens it. The dog rushes a wild joyous excitement. It begins a wild frolic on the hillside before the cottag downright silliness of the animal's joyful exuberant forc of reluctant smile to Prendick's lips.

dialogues.text: A curtain of rain falls across the downland, turned to mo gold by the dying light, descending as a blessing upon th green hills and patchwork farmsteads. The dog comes running along the crest of a hill, rejoicin at the rain, eyes brimming with a simple animal happiness to a halt, shaking itself, turning its snout towards the light. The rain has stopped, the sky is clearing. Its master walks now to stand beside it, his hands in his contemplating the same awesome view. Then Prendick bends pat the dog as it leaps up, putting its paws against his lick his face that is wet with rain or tears. Prendick looks deep into the sweet liquid eyes of the do FADE TO BLACK.
